comment.author: 10064494@N07
comment._content: Your scans are way too over-sharpened.

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: Hi gregoreverb, I suggest looking at the high-resolution tiff image we have for this photochrom at www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2002696899/. Our scanning specs for this collection can be found at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/pgz/digitizing.html This is probably also a good time to remind people that these photochroms are not actually photographic. A black and white negative is used to make colored lithographic stones that print the various colors. The final product is a print that resembles a color photograph. You can read more about the photochrom process at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/pgz/process.html.

comment.author: 10064494@N07
comment._content:
Thanks for your reply, Jon.

Yes, they do look much better at full resolution. I understand the photochrom process. I thought they might have been hand-colored black and white photographs.
